title: As Draghi Gets Ready to Exit, His Legacy Remains Contested
text:
FRANKFURT—When European Central Bank President Mario Draghi presented his final jolt of stimulus for the eurozone to the central bank’s rate-setting committee Thursday, he faced a rebellion.

At least seven board members of the 25-member body, including his closest aide and the heads of the French, German, Dutch and Austrian central banks, opposed his plans to restart a multi-billion-euro bond-buying program.

But having flagged a possible stimulus for months, Mr. Draghi had raised expectations in financial markets that would have been tricky to reverse.

His plan, which aims to protect the eurozone from a global slowdown, went forward. The ECBcut its key interest rate by 10 basis points to minus 0.5% and launched an open-ended bond-purchasing program, known as quantitative easing, that will add to the bank’s €2.6 trillion ($2.876 trillion) mountain of eurozone debt.

“Such a far-reaching package was not necessary,” Jens Weidmann, head of Germany’s central bank, told the Germany daily Bild in Saturday’s advance edition. The paper on Friday featured a doctored photo of Mr. Draghi as a vampire and a headline saying, “That’s how Count Draghila is sucking our accounts dry.”

The revolt, coming just weeks before Mr. Draghi steps down as ECB president, reflects growing skepticism and fatigue with his policies and leadership style—problems his successor, departing International Monetary Fund Managing Director Christine Lagarde, must contend with when she takes over on Nov. 1.

Mr. Draghi talks with his successor, IMF Managing Director Christine Lagarde, at a eurozone finance ministers’ meeting in Luxembourg in 2015. Photo: francois lenoir/Reuters

While the 72-year-old Italian has built an institution that is vastly more powerful than the one he inherited, it has also become a deeply divisive one, introducing policies that strayed into political territory and brought it into conflict with elected governments.

At the same time, policies that saved the currency area from collapse—immortalized by Mr. Draghi’s 2012 promise to do “whatever it takes” to save the euro—are fading, while their adverse side effects are growing, critics say, including asset-price bubbles and an increase in unproductive “zombie” companies that survive on rock-bottom lending rates.

In acting boldly to save the euro, Mr. Draghi vastly expanded the ECB’s powers, creating new policy tools that halted an investor panic and engineered a robust recovery of the eurozone economy.

“I grade his performance as straight-A,” said Janet Yellen, former chairwoman of the Federal Reserve. “He’s pushed the ECB in a much more aggressive direction, which has been appropriate in responding to the downturn following the financial crisis….I see him as having changed the mind-set” at the ECB.

As EU member states struggled to respond to the sovereign-debt crisis in the years after 2009, Mr. Draghi stepped into the breach, making him the most powerful economic actor in the region.

Former Fed Chairwoman Janet Yellen and ECB President Mario Draghi walking the grounds at the Jackson Hole economic symposium in August 2017. Photo: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg News

“Until then [the ECB’s] focus was inflation, inflation, inflation,” said Pierre Moscovici, a former French finance minister. “Its purpose became saving and defending the euro. It was a second birth for the ECB.”

But the ECB’s aggressive monetary policy generated bitter opposition, particularly from Germany. With a robust economy and an antipathy to expansive monetary policy, Germany worried that the ECB’s massive purchases of government debt essentially subsidized spendthrift governments, particularly Italy’s, and spared them the painful work of reforming their economies. Moreover, negative rates hurt Germany’s cautious savers.

Mr. Weidmann, a member of the rate-setting committee, compared ECB policies to drugs and testified against the ECB at Germany’s top court.

Mr. Draghi hit back, complaining in public about colleagues who said “Nein zu Allem”—German for “No to everything”—while offering no alternative strategy.

In June, Mr. Draghi publicly accused some national eurozone central banks of stirring populist feelings against the ECB. The next morning, Mr. Weidmann told Mr. Draghi he was surprised by the remarks and asked if they were directed at him, according to people familiar with the matter.

“You and Klaas,” Mr. Draghi shot back, referring to Klaas Knot, head of the Dutch central bank head and another longtime critic of the ECB’s easy-money policies.

Messrs. Draghi, Knot and Weidmann declined to comment. In a statement Friday, Mr. Knot said QE was “disproportionate to the present economic conditions” and could be ineffective.

For most of his tenure since 2011, Mr. Draghi has effectively squelched resistance to his policies. His speeches often became platforms to set the bank on course for action and pre-empt debate. Officials say Mr. Draghi has also been less concerned than his predecessor, the Frenchman Jean-Claude Trichet, about having all 19 eurozone central banks support key decisions.

Dinners before the meetings, which stretched into the night under Mr. Trichet, now end by 10 p.m. That reflects the hyper-efficient style of Mr. Draghi, a former Goldman Sachs banker who trained at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, as well as a desire to avoid leaks, said one former ECB official. “At six o’clock at every Eurogroup meeting [of eurozone finance ministers], he just gets up and leaves,” said one eurozone official.

German Bundesbank President Jens Weidmann has been a vocal critic of the ECB’s easy-money policies under Mr. Draghi. Photo: yuri gripas/Reuters

Mr. Draghi instead crafts policy with a close circle of allies who meet every Tuesday in a meeting room outside his office. The ECB’s rate-setting committee meets one floor up, in a room featuring a sculpture of Europe on the ceiling, nicknamed the “Jedi chamber” by one international official for its cloistered atmosphere.

“He gave the governing council little choice,” said Panicos Demetriades, who sat on the ECB’s governing council from 2012-14 as governor of Cyprus’s central bank. “The way [the ECB’s bond-buying] programs came about had a lot to do with Mario.”

Mr. Draghi has, however, quietly made efforts to win the support of the German government. He met nine times with German government officials in the 12 months through May, more than twice as often as he did with officials of any other nationality, according to his official diary.

With his final blast of easy money, the tensions between Mr. Draghi and the Germans have again come to the fore. At his press conference Thursday, he pointedly called out Berlin for its fierce resistance to loosening fiscal policy, a move that he says could help revive a flagging German economy that is weighing on the rest of the eurozone.

“Almost all the things that you see in Europe, the creation of more than 11 million jobs over a short period of time, the recovery, the sustained growth for several quarters were by and large produced by our monetary policy,” Mr. Draghi said. “There was very little else.”

Former Greek Finance Minister Yanis Varoufakis, who famously sparred with the ECB over the country’s debt bailout, both praised and criticized Mr. Draghi, giving him credit for taking action when eurozone governments were unwilling to enact reforms, but saying that his bond-buying program was closer to fiscal policy than monetary policy.

He “bought time for Europe’s politicians to get their act together, via means that were smart and terrible,” Mr. Varoufakis said. “But they did not take advantage of the time he bought them.”

In leaving the ECB with an enormous balance sheet and the prospect of years of negative rates, Mr. Draghi’s legacy is in doubt.

His policies may fare better under Ms. Lagarde than a more hawkish successor like Mr. Weidmann, who was considered a favorite to win the job. Ms. Lagarde has indicated she will continue Mr. Draghi’s easy-money policies while possibly fine-tuning them and reassessing their costs.

But one eurozone official who has been critical of Mr. Draghi compared his legacy with those of former Federal Reserve chairmen Paul Volcker—widely credited with ending the high levels of U.S. inflation during the 1970s and early 1980s—and Alan Greenspan, whose policies have since been criticized for contributing to the dot-com bubble and the subprime mortgage crisis.

“Greenspan was revered at the time and Volcker was hated, but now it’s Volcker who has the stronger reputation among economic historians,” the official said. “Draghi’s legacy isn’t assured.”

Write to Tom Fairless at tom.fairless@wsj.com
description: A revolt among ECB rate setters didn’t stop President Mario Draghi from delivering a last stimulus, but their skepticism and fatigue with his policies and leadership style suggest the far-reaching changes he instituted aren’t guaranteed to stay.
